title: Can a poem have no stanzas or do I have to break my poem up into stanzas? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think if it doesn’t have any stanzas it is just a blank sheet, isn’t even a monolithic block of text that’s a “poem” considered a single stanza? Sure I think your question is does it need to be broken up into blocks, the answer is no it doesn’t, I’ve seen many that aren’t as well as many that are, however that being said, try to look into the way you read your poem and how it’s structured… you might find some natural breaks that you wish you separate. If it has a rhyming scheme that’s a good way to look for where the repetition cycle begins and ends, voila - a stanza, if you want it to be… If you still are having trouble blocking it into chunks, then you still don’t HAVE to split it up, I think the readers would prefer you use your whitespace to the advantage of the poem to the best of your ability, but that being said, your case is your case and I don’t know a whole lot about your poem, it may be that its quite fine not to use stanza breaks. There are some interesting elements of this, for example: if your text in the poem is all about not having a line between things then it is illustrating the poems point not to… There are no real rules here - to have rules in a poem, you either need to make them yourself or choose to follow a form that is already defined - which generally sets out its own rules or structure. You may get some inspiration from referring to poems others have written, or you may not, your work is probably unique to you, so anything others say is pretty much all just guidelines. I know saying that isn’t all that helpful, but without specifics or any kind of understanding of your poem I can’t be of more help to you. All I can do is wish you luck … you are the author, it is your choice how you present your poem and what choices you make with it.

A poem can be a long stretch of lines and maybe get a publisher's maximum characters per line or lines per poem. So commercially, there could be restrictions beyond your initial query. The way that poetry was usually presented was in a portrait style poetry book. So line lengths were helpful in creating text to fit the page and the font and style. You haven't used the comment section for your query to offer a link to your poetry. A poem is often regarded as having verse gaps, yet that doesn't apply to some styles that we can check using Google search or the poemhunter poetry website. Some poetry is going to use a few lines or a dozen or fourteen or just carry on till all is displayed. A book doesn't offer some scrolling effect like a web page does. A video on YouTube would be better served if offering verse gaps. The poemhunter website creates videos of our poems and adds these to the poetry web pages or on the dailymotion videos website. So we can view these when searching for a poet's name or the poemhunter username there.:The modern trend of the Internet and computers as well as Internet tablets will offer us the landscape format screen display. Some websites like QUORA maintain a central column but other websites use more of the screen width. A safe screen width isn't going to use the maximum screen width. Web pages are usually created with adequate pixel values for left and right margins or blank space. So this is why I choose that many of my longer poems are going to be displayed differently. Usually, I prefer the 8-6-8-6 syllables per line as with common metre hymns. For the Internet, I combine lines 1 and 2 then 3 and 4. I can get 32 lines to be displayed as 16 lines instead. That way, more of the poem appears on a single screen display.:You can see how this works on my 2,700+ poems on the poemhunter website which offers visitors the poet's poetry as a free download of an e-book in the PDF file format. No adverts, just poetry.:So maybe you can combine lines to create a shorter looking piece of poetry that could be displayed without verse breaks. Otherwise, count the lines and see if these fit verses with 4, 6, 8, 10 or 12. Choose a 24-lined poem and you can use 2, 4, 6, 8 or the 12 as verse line options, rather than just every 4 lines then a verse gap.:You choose and you edit to suit the line lengths... unless offering to a poetry publisher that has its own preferences, styles or guidelines. Same again with poetry competitions.:

I subscribe to poem-a-day from Academy of American Poets I get a poem each day in my email in-box. Of the last 25 poems that I received, approximately 1 in 5 were not divided into stanzas, even though they were long enough for division. Here’s one: Small Craft Talk Warning Dean Young All poetry is about hope.A scarecrow walks into a bar.An abandoned space station falls to earth.When probing the monster’s brain,you’re probably probing your own.A beautiful woman becomes a ghost.I hope I never miscalculate the dosagethat led to the infarctionof my lab rabbit again.All poetry is a form of hope.Not certain, just actuallike love and other traffic circles.I cried on that airplane too,midwest patchwork belowlike a board game on whichmighty forces kick apart the avatars.I always wanted to be the racecarbut usually ended up a thumbtack.When I was young, sitting in a treecounted as preparation and latermaybe a little whoopie in the morgue.So go ahead, thaw the alien, breakthe pentagram but watch out forthe institutional hood ornaments.It’s not a museum, it’s a hive.The blood may be fakebut the bleeding’s not.

You are not compelled to break up your poem into stanzas, plural. You can have a long poem in a single stanza. You can have a poem that is a single line, one stanza poem. You can have a poem that appears on the page in the shape of an apple. You can do anything you like. Create a new form. Start a revolution. Be original. No-one wants to read the same poem over and over, just by different poets.

In some ways, a stanza is a form of punctuation. Consider whether some lines will be more powerful, or moving if they’re grouped together in units, rather than running on as stream of consciousness does. Ultimately, it’s always your choice.
Free verse is poetry that doesn’t need any rhyme or meter. In general it tends to be a more modern form of expression, often about everyday things. Nothing epic about it. Write and enjoy. Gary Taryle
